summary: The Internet (or internet)[a] is the global system of interconnected computer networks that uses the Internet protocol suite (TCP/IP)[b] to communicate between networks and devices. It is a network of networks that comprises private, public, academic, business, and government networks of local to gl...
title: Internet

quiz.question: What is the global system of interconnected computer networks called?
quiz.explanation: The Internet is a network of networks that comprises private, public, academic, business, and government networks of local to global scope.

quiz.question: What is the organization that maintains the definitions of the two principal name spaces on the Internet?
quiz.explanation: The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) is responsible for the overarching definitions of the two principal name spaces on the Internet.

quiz.question: Who proposed the idea of a universal network?
quiz.explanation: J. C. R. Licklider proposed the idea of a universal network while working at Bolt Beranek & Newman and, later, leading the Information Processing Techniques Office at the Advanced Research Projects Agency (ARPA).

quiz.question: What is the activity of the non-profit Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF)?
options: Maintaining the definitions of the two principal name spaces on the Internet
quiz.explanation: The technical underpinning and standardization of the core protocols is an activity of the non-profit Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF).

quiz.question: When was the word 'internetted' first used?
quiz.explanation: The word 'internetted' was used as early as 1849, meaning interconnected or interwoven.

quiz.question: What is the global collection of web pages, documents and other web resources linked by hyperlinks and URLs?
quiz.explanation: The World Wide Web, or the Web, is the global collection of web pages, documents and other web resources linked by hyperlinks and URLs.

quiz.question: Who developed packet switching technology independently in 1965?
quiz.explanation: Research into packet switching started in the work of Paul Baran at RAND in the early 1960s and, independently, Donald Davies at the United Kingdom's National Physical Laboratory in 1965.

quiz.question: What is the organization that commissioned research and development for the Internet in the 1970s?
quiz.explanation: The Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) of the United States Department of Defense commissioned research and development for the Internet in the 1970s.

quiz.question: What is the term for a group of smaller networks?
quiz.explanation: The term Internet may also refer to any group of smaller networks.

quiz.question: What is the organization that recommends the lowercase form of the word 'Internet'?
quiz.explanation: The AP Stylebook recommends the lowercase form of the word 'Internet' in every case.
